document.heading: Residency Requirement Reinstatement Amendment Act of 1998

history.narrative: Law 12-138, the “Residency Requirement Reinstatement Amendment Act of 1998,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 12-137, which was referred to the Committee on Government Operations. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on March 17, 1998, and April 7, 1998, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on April 22, 1998, it was assigned Act No. 12-340 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 12-138 became effective on July 24, 1998.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be known as the "Residency Requirement Reinstatement Amendment Act of 1998 Sec. 2. The District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978, effective March 3, 1979 (D.C. Law 2-139; D.C. Code § 1-601.1 et seq is amended as follows a) Section 801 (D.C. Residency Requirement a)(1) Any person hired by a Service created, after the effective date of the Residency Requirement Reinstatement Amendment Act of 1998, shall be a resident of the District of Columbia or shall obtain residency within 180 days of the effective date of appointment and shall maintain residency during the course of their employment with the District of Columbia Government.
